DOC.HEAD: Bush: U.S. Troops to Stay `As Long as It Takes'
Eds: SUBS 10th graf: ``The Pentagon,'' with latest casualty figures, 21 deaths, 208 wounded
DOC.TEXT: President Bush vowed Thursday that American troops would scour Panama ``as long as it takes'' to capture Manuel Antonio Noriega. He said the loss of American lives in the military action ``has been worth it'' and called the U.S. commitment open-ended. Expressing sorrow over the deaths, Bush said ``military casualties are a burden which a nation must endure and all presidents have to face up to, but which we can never accept.'' Several congressmen called for the troops to be brought home quickly, though one _ Rep. Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee _ said some might have to remain as policemen until ``Christmas eve a year from now.'' Bush said the operation was ``open-ended as far as going after Noriega, open-ended as far as restoration of order in Panama.'' A day after ordering 9,500 fighting men into Panama, to join more than 13,000 already stationed there, Bush said the military mission ``is not over, but pretty well wrapped up.'' U.S. forces encountered sporadic firing in Panama City but were reported in control of several key points in the city, including the legislative building, said Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams. Officials said most units of Noriega's Panamanian Defense Forces had fled into the jungles, and that U.S. troops may be ordered to follow them. Bush said that with Noriega on the run and a new president, Guillermo Endara, in place, ``the government is beginning to function and the man (Noriega) controls no forces. And he's out. But, yes, I won't be satisfied until we see him come to justice.'' Bush made his remarks at a White House news conference at the very hour a military aircraft arrived in Dover, Del., bearing the bodies of some of the Americans killed in Panama. The Pentagon said 21 troops had been killed in action, 208 were wounded and one was missing. In addition, an American civilian, Candy Helin, 43, was killed. A schoolteacher of gifted children at a U.S. government school in Panama, she was killed by stray fire from the Panamanian Defense Forces, officials said. Military hospitals in San Antonio, Texas, reported they were treating about 190 troops evacuated from Panama, a higher count than reported at the Pentagon. Asked if the attempt to catch Noriega had been worth the loss of life, Bush said, ``I have to answer: Yes, it has been worth it.'' U.S. officials said 59 Panamanian soldiers had been killed and 66 wounded. Army Lt. Gen. Tom Kelly said U.S. troops had taken 1,500 prisoners, most of them regulars from the Panamanian Defense Force. Bush said 11 people said to have been abducted by Panamanian troops from a Smithsonian research facility had been freed. However, Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, said there were other reports of an unknown number of Americans being held in three separate incidents. The Pentagon said the U.S. offer of a $1 million bounty for Noriega had prompted many calls but no results. ``We've had a lot of nibbles,'' said Rear Adm. Ted Sheafer, an intelligence specialist for the Joint Chiefs of Staff. ``Suddenly the number of reports on his location has gone up dramatically,'' he said. ``A lot of it turns out to be very bogus.'' Bush said, ``That's $1 million bucks I'd be very happy to sign the check for,'' and he joked that Noriega's wanted poster ``will be in every post office in town.'' Noriega is under indictment in the United States on drug charges. The general dropped from sight and eluded capture as American troops landed in Panama. ``The good news _ he's out of power,'' Bush said. ``The bad news _ he has not yet been brought to justice. ... There is a certain level of frustration on that account.'' Bush said, ``I won't be satisfied until we see him come to justice.'' Asked how long he would chase Noriega, Bush said, ``As long as it takes.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had suggested that some elements of the U.S. force might be withdrawn by Christmas, although the White House later suggested that might be overly optimistic. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We certainly aren't willing to give a timetable to it. But everyone recognizes this is not going to be a case of going in Wednesday and coming out Thursday. ``The new government doesn't have an easy task,'' Fitzwater said at his own news briefing. ``Don't look for results overnight.'' Bush used the word ``invade'' to refer to the U.S. operation in Panama but caught himself and changed it to ``send in those troops down into Panama.'' He acknowledged that he had changed course from October, when he was criticized for not supporting or joining the effort by Panamanian officers to overthrow Noriega. The president said, ``I think what changed my mind was ... the death of the Marine, brutalizing, really obscene torture of the Navy lieutenant and the threat of sexual abuse and the terror inflicted on that Navy lieutenant's wife, the declaration of war by Noriega.'' Bush said he needs to spell out those incidents to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose government has criticized the intervention. Bush said that with instances of harassment and death, ``Mr. Gorbachev, please understand this president is going to do something about it.'' Meanwhile, Fitzwater said Bush still anticipates attending a Feb. 15 drug summit with Latin American leaders in Cartagena, Colombia, even though Peru's president, Alan Garcia, pulled his ambassador from Washington in protest of the Panamanian intervention and called for postponing the summit.
